text: [Music]
in this series we've been learning about
my friends musical instrument the new
which is a chromatic didgeridoo you
might be curious like I was about my
friend's background as an inventor what
else has he invented would you like to
know listen to part of my interview with
Eric and then I'll ask you some
questions to check your understanding
I have to ask because you don't just say
hey I'm going to invent an instrument I
mean there has to be some background to
this can you tell me how'd you ever try
to invent things or reinvent things I've
made a lot of strange musical
instruments in my workshop over the
years I made a slide bagpipe I had made
three note didgeridoos and a slide
didgeridoo it made what else a slide
saxophone pyrrha phone which is an
instrument that uses fire to create the
sound with all kinds of strange things
the short answer is yes yes
[Applause]
okay first question does Eric have a
strong background as an inventor the
answer is yes when I asked Eric had you
ever tried to invent or reinvent things
his answer was I've made a lot of
strange musical instruments over the
years let's write the verb form I've
made
okay second question before the new had
Eric ever invented any other kind of
didgeridoo again the answer is yes he
said I had made a three note didgeridoo
and a slide didgeridoo let's write that
verb form okay I've made I had made
which one is the present perfect this
one right a present form of have plus
the past participle do you remember why
we use the present perfect we use the
present perfect to refer to the general
past a general past experience but also
events or actions that could occur again
in the future
Eric is an inventor he invented things
in the past and it's likely he'll invent
more things in the future that's why he
said I've made a lot of strange musical
instruments however he said I had made a
three note didgeridoo and a slide
didgeridoo he's referring to specific
actions or events that occurred in the
past and we understand that those two
other didgeridoos were made before the
new the new was made last year and
before that point in time to other kinds
of digitus were made this is our past
perfect and that's what we're going to
talk about now the past perfect is
mainly used to refer to actions or
events that took place before a specific
period in time so we're looking at a
past point in time in looking at what
happened before that point these two
events were points in time must be clear
to the speaker
the listener the past perfect is not all
that different from the present perfect
in terms of form instead of using a
present form of our helping verb we use
a past form had to form the past perfect
we use pad for all subjects plus the
past participle for regular verbs that's
an IDI ending try tried but because in
English we have a lot of irregular verbs
there are irregular past participles
like made make made these forms you just
have to learn and remember
remember we mainly use the past perfect
to refer to actions or events that took
place before a certain past point in
time
be sure you understand the difference
between the past perfect and the simple
past the simple past refers to one
specific past point or period the past
perfect refers to an earlier past
pointer period the second or later point
in time must be clear to the listener
either through context or the use of
time expressions such as before 2012 by
the age of 30 consider this example
before he performed the song he had
practiced it at home many times practice
is the earlier of the two actions
when you form the pass perfect
remember it uses had plus a past
participle for all subjects here are
some more examples I had met him you had
lived abroad he had told me it had
changed you see examples of regular
verbs and irregular verbs
remember to use the helping verb had
both in negative forms and in short
answers we use had not or the
contraction hadn't plus a past
participle as in I hadn't known that or
she hadn't finished in response to the
question had you told anyone your secret
one can respond yes I had or no I hadn't
let's do a quick check read the two
statements to yourself and then tell me
which one explains that I sat down
because I was done with my work my work
was finished the answer is number two
first I finished my work and then I sat
down so the past perfect refers to the
earlier of two actions in contrast the
first statement means i sat down and
then I finished my work i sat down
perhaps in order to finish my work
this is the end of part 1 be sure to go
on to part 2 to learn about the past
perfect progressive
